We condition the model by quantifying the degree of “extremeness" of the observed sample, which allows us to sample from different parts of the distribution. We demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed method on the CHIRPS precipitation dataset. 1 Introduction Noticeable shifts in climate patterns have been observed over the last few decades, including an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events. Such events often result in severe societal impacts, with risks to agriculture, access to water resources, energy management and transportation, among others [ 1]. Therefore, accurate modeling and prediction of climate patterns is of immense interest. For instance, process-based models, like crop growth or hydrological models, that are used to assess potential impacts on climate-sensitive sectors [ 2,3] generally require long time series of high-resolution weather data [2, 4]. Stochastic weather generators have been widely used to provide synthetic weather series that represent plausible climate scenarios to the impact models [5, 6, 2, 3]. The first stochastic weather generators date to the 1980s [ 7], and since then, several techniques have been explored with different levels of complexity [ 4]. However, traditional models often fail to generate extremes such as droughts or flooding [ 2]. Some weather generators can be conditioned on external variables, e.g. [ 2], which produces weather sequences consistent with temperature and precipitation seasonal forecasts. That is, the external variables control the generation of weather fields. The idea of controlling weather Tackling Climate Change with Machine Learning: workshop at NeurIPS 2021.field synthesis is essential for producing what-if scenarios to study its particular effects on sensitive areas. For example, local governments may need to investigate the risks of floods in a region subject to consecutive days of plausible heavy rainfall events. In recent years, machine learning based generative models have achieved notable success in modeling high dimensional complex distributions, which has led to their application in stochastic weather generation. For instance, Variational AutoEncoders (V AEs) [ 8] have been used to generate precipi- tation data and control synthesis by sampling from different regions of the latent space [ 9], while Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) [ 10] based approaches have been shown to generate realistic precipitation samples [ 11] and model weather extremes [ 12]. In this work, we make use of the GAN framework for stochastic weather modeling, focusing on conditional generation. Conditional GANs [13] have shown great success in several tasks involving an input controlling the data generation, such as image-to-image translation [ 14,15]. More recently, researchers have explored these models for weather generation [ 12,16]. In this paper, we leverage the conditional GAN framework to generate synthetic precipitation scenarios. For this, we propose a simple yet effective conditioning metric and empirically demonstrate that it allows to accurately model and sample from different quantiles of precipitation in the data distribution. 2 Methods and Experiments Data For our experiments, we use the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS) [ 17] rainfall data set. Fig. 1b indeed verifies that most precipitation in the region occurs during the selected months (roughly between days numbered in the range 150–290). Current state-of-the-art process-based agriculture models rely on high-resolution climate data during the growing season for accurate crop yield estimation. However, high-resolution climate data for future climates is unavailable and must be simulated, which becomes expensive when considering multiple possible climate scenarios. Deep generative models leveraging neural networks have shown promise in modeling high-dimensional distributions. We cast the climate scenario simulation problem in a generative modeling framework, leveraging the Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) framework to simulate synthetic climate scenarios. We condition the model by quantifying the degree of "extremeness" of observed samples, allowing us to sample from different parts of the distribution. We demonstrate the efficacy of our method on the CHIRPS precipitation dataset.

Notable shifts in climate patterns have been observed over the last few decades, including increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events. These events have severe societal impacts, affecting agriculture, water resources, energy management, and transportation. Accurate climate pattern modeling and prediction is of great interest. Process-based models, such as crop growth or hydrological models, require long time series of high-resolution weather data. Stochastic weather generators have been used to provide synthetic weather series representing plausible climate scenarios for impact models. Traditional models often fail to generate extremes like droughts or flooding.

Machine learning-based generative models have achieved success in modeling high-dimensional complex distributions, leading to their application in stochastic weather generation. Variational AutoEncoders (VAEs) have been used to generate precipitation data and control synthesis by sampling from different regions of the latent space. Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) based approaches have generated realistic precipitation samples and modeled weather extremes. We make use of the GAN framework for stochastic weather modeling, focusing on conditional generation. Conditional GANs have shown success in tasks involving input-controlled data generation, such as image-to-image translation. We leverage the conditional GAN framework to generate synthetic precipitation scenarios, proposing a simple yet effective conditioning metric.

We use the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS) rainfall dataset for our experiments. The dataset consists of daily precipitation fields with a spatial resolution of 0.05 degrees, spanning from 1981-2021. We use a bounding box of 6.4 × 6.4 degrees, equating to a resolution of 128 × 128 pixels, where each pixel represents a geographical region spanning 0.05 × 0.05 degrees. The chosen spatial region is bound by latitudes (18.0, 24.4) and longitudes (74, 80.4), a region in central India. We focus on precipitation samples between June-October, which corresponds to the monsoon season in central India. This sub-interval captures most of the variation in total rainfall, allowing us to sub-sample from the large amount of samples without losing fidelity.
